ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I built an understanding of some exceptional philosophers of the 21st century, and how their ideas interact with each other and with our current world. This was the first in-depth philosophy class I took at Yale, and I am so grateful that it was with Smith. I was surrounded by brilliant peers, felt excited to the readings, and came to class each week eager to discuss.

Overview and discussion of 4 major political philosophers of the 20th century. Themes include liberal pluralism and its discontents, foundations of modern conservatism, the theologico-political problem, the relationship between the city and the philosopher, critiques of historicism and positivism, esotericism, and the craft of statesmanship.
I really developed my in class discussion skills through our seminars and my presentation.
Learned a lot of political philosophy from the four main authors of the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings and professor were definitely the strength. I do wish that we had the opportunity to get peer feedback on our essays, or something like that, just because this was fairly new to me. But truly this was one of the best courses, if not the best, I have taken; I learned quite a bit about the philosophical questions and ideas that are behind many modern ideologies and dispositions (esp. Marxism and Conservatism).

The content was interesting but a bit amorphous. Hard to discern exactly what I took away from this class but that might just be the nature of modern political philosophy. Note that all of the authors are mainly reactionary and are writing about philosophers before them, so theyre very different from the political philosophy that you read in DS.

Strengths: encourages students to engage deeply with material by creating discussion-leading questions, good array of philosophical thought to study, prof smith!

Weaknesses: amount of reading led to some topics being rushed

Strengths: this seminar was particularly strong because of the other students -- a lot of smart undergraduates and graduate students. The authors on the syllabus are strong, but to be honest, I don't necessarily think the readings chosen were all their most interesting works. Also, in spite of how impressive the group was, discussion felt too expositional and not focused enough on philosophy.
The syllabus was certainly a strength, and the in-class discussion was engaging. I enjoyed the setup of the course and the seminar atmosphere. No weaknesses come to mind immediately.
Strengths: excellent reading list, knowledgable professor, manageable workload. Weaknesses: poorly led seminars dominated by a few students and often boring.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I could not recommend it more. Professor Smith is a national treasure.
I would recommend, but the class definitely skews to a certain demographic of people, so be wary of that if youre interested.
Absolutely! This class challenged me to think in a different way about topics we take for granted and I think that is crucial to intellectual growth.
Yes I would. If you are at all interest in political philosophy, Strauss, especially, is a must read and Smith is the guy to do it with at Yale.
Yes, if they are serious about reading, discussing, and writing about political theory. I am very glad I took it.

Maybe. Great readings, but seminars were not the best. May be more inclined to recommend if the class were either taught as a lecture or had less people in the seminar. Grading seemed a bit arbitrary.

extras.title: PLSC 296 01/PLSC 638 01 - Political Philosophy in a Time
